subject: Re: [junit] Re: A Simple doubt
msgSnippet: ... I have never been on a project where people have devoted the necessary time and attention to maintaining test suites any further than These are Programmer
messageBody:
>So said Jason Rogers on 2003-05-22 --------------------
>On Thu, 22 May 2003 19:24:43 -0000, "Dave Astels" <dave@...> said:
>> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Jason Rogers <jacaetevha@f...> wrote:
>> > Do this instead...
>> >
>> > public static Test suite(){
>> > TestSuite suite = new TestSuite(TestClass1.class);
>> > ^^^^^^^^^^
>> > return suite;
>> > }
>>
>> There's no reason to create a suite method anyway... the framework
>> will take care of that. Getting in the habit of creating our own
>> suite, can lead to order dependancies since you're setting the test
>> order explicitly.
>>
>> Dave
>
>For a simple case like he was writing (to which I was referring), you
>don't need it. True. However, on larger projects I think the having
>TestSuites is very essential. For instance, on my current gig we have
>written over 1900 test fixtures. They include typical unit tests,
>functional tests, and integration tests. All of the tests further break
>down via sub-systems, the type of functionality, etc. All of these tests
>are run before code is checked in (and often at other times), but there
>are plenty of times when I am only interested in running a subset of
>tests (one or two suites). It provides quicker feedback since the suite
>including all tests takes approx. 300 seconds to run (which is much
>better than the 800 seconds it used to take :).

I have never been on a project where people have devoted the necessary time and attention to maintaining test suites any further than "These are Programmer Tests and Those are Customer Tests". Mike Bowler gets all the credit for having even that much discipline.

I would like to work on such a project, though.

Take care.
